titleStmt.title: Joseph L. Taylor et al. to Thomas E. Bramlette
CWG6842

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Thomas E. Bramlette: Governor's official correspondence file, petitions for pardons, remissions, and respites 1863-1867

body.p:
To his Excellency Thomas E Bramlette
Govenor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky

The undersigned have Known the petitioner Jno W Harris for many years and have known, him during that period of time to be a quiet peaceable man, industrious, and so far as our observation extends indisposed to get into personal broils or difficulties.
He has a young family and it would affect him seriously in his pecuniary affairs to pay the fine imposed on him by the Fayette Court.

Believing from all we have heard of his case, that it is one that calls for the exercise of Executive Clemency, we feel no hesitation in joining in the prayer of the petitioner of said Harris and a majority of the jury who tried him, for a remission of his fine, so far as you can remit it

Jos L Taylor
H H. Culbertson
Thos. S. Edwards
B, Craig
P. B. Morris Police Judge
Jn, M, Wasson
F. A. Blackburn
D. Thornton
J V Hoskins
Geo. T. Hord.
W W George Jr
David P Robb clk. W. C. C.
W M. Dickey J. P. W. C
J M Combs Sheriff Woodford
L B Peters C. W. C
Wm W. George
Jos, S. Woolfolk
D. M, Ball
